- All that copy-paste procedure causes some disorientation. I suggest you use a script template only for the part of loading and pre-processing the data, and the exporting part in the end. It is good practice to re-write the code of the rest of the script (i.e. the modelling and model training part). I think it helps with learning, and after all, they are just 5 models. 
- In the exercise statement of Neural Networks, when you ask for forecasting 4 periods, I thought you where talking about the period of a cycle (i.e. the season). So I have forecasted 16 quarters, since each cyclic period have 4 quarters. oss. to measure the period I've decomposed the time series and looked at the seasonal pattern.

Overall, a solid course to build a basic foundation on different forecasting models. The pacing was good and the code was easy to follow. I would recommend it to anyone interested in this topic, but in my opinion, there could be some improvements.

It would be much more helpful if there was some sort of revision or tweaks made to the model to see how it could be improved rather than just saying "it looks better" or "it is not so great". For example, the Prophet + XGBoost results were worse than the regular Prophet results, but no explanation or discussion was made about it. Felt incomplete.
2) There is a lot of wasted time opening and copying/pasting the same scripts over and over again for every kind of model.

Course Name: Forecasting Models and Time Series for Business in Python
Comment: Hi Diego, I am enjoying your course so far, as I can see you brought in your professional expertise and applied methods into the course, which is of practical importance, no doubt. The visuals are great, and your Python coding is fun and approachable. However, at moments I caught myself being a bit frustrated because the theoretical and statistical underpinning of the course is very limited. So to be able to properly understand these models I was forced to constantly switch between your course and university textbooks in econometrics and time series, even though I took intro stats and econometrics in college. Given that I need this for work and I believe other students need that too, it is difficult to intuitively apply methods in the real-world setting while equipped with a rudimentary grasp of statistics behind them. I think intuition is built in part through studying theory.  So to make this a one-stop-shop, the course would greatly benefit from at least some math and stats to describe the concepts behind the models. I understand you refrained from that approach as you probably wanted to open this topic to non-math professionals, and that makes sense to a degree, but I think you ought to make more effort toward striking the right balance between theory and practice.  Of course, this is my personal view, based on my background and needs, and I am sure that other folks with different objectives and backgrounds can get a lot of value from the course.  I would still recommend the course to everyone. Descent job Diego, keep it up!
